message:
Anyone here have a deep understanding of  hidden markov models (viterbi algorithm), conditional random fields or recurrent neural networks and their applications in pattern spotting from a continuous stream without explicit segmentation?

Thanks

data.message: بس للاسف انا with explicit segmentation

The plethora of terminologies you've included in your post. It's like Ask Jeeves all over again but without NLP. 

Just when you think people would stop calling sentence parsing + word graphing and some dependency graphing an NLU system... /rant

Edit: See what I did up there? Lol..

Anyway, what we know about your post now, is that you're attempting to do some sort of pattern spotting on a continuous stream of entities that have no clear segmentation. Uh, okay... And?

Are you building a keyword spotting system? Everything you've said in the post aligns with that. RNN, viterbi algorithms, continuous stream (of text, I presume). 

Throwing a bunch of buzz words together without an clear intent or a solid technical question is hardly a good conversation starter.

Thanks for replying :)

Sorry for ambiguity, the continuous stream represents a one dimensional analog signal, i've some meaningful patterns that might occur within the continuous stream, these patterns have temporal variations (not fixed time), i.e pattern #1 could take 5 ms or 7 ms or 10 ms, but the overall shape of the pattern in the same.

what i want to do is to make live decoding for the continuous stream into a series of meaningful pattern classes given that, i don't know how to know where each pattern will begin or end in the continuous stream , also the stream might have non meaningful patterns that i'm not interested in and should discard from decoding.

What i've currently implemented is a classifier that can classify any of these patterns given that the signal has a defined beginning and ending,

This guy does Neural Networks -> Mohab Elkaref
Not sure about the other buzzwords though :D
Edit: after giving it more thought, I feel this might not be close to his field of focus, but let's see.

OK I'll keep this short. The only successful attempts at something similar that I know of are (1) a speech recognition system that uses a combination of Long Short-term Memory (lstm) networks together with a bi-directional RNN. Look for a paper authored by Alex Graves and some Canadian guy. (2) The PhD dissertation of Felix Gers. He used LSTMs as well to predict random spikes in a continuous signal. You can download his cpp code for that, but its an absolute bitch to read. 

Can't help you out much with HMMs I'm afraid, but if I were you I'd explore them further IF I was comfortable with Support Vector Machines.

Hope that helps.
